title: Pieter Quast
text:
Pieter Jansz. Quast (1605 or '06 – buried 29 May 1647) was a <a href="Dutch%20Golden%20Age%20painter">Dutch Golden Age painter</a> and draughtsman, mostly producing small social <a href="genre%20painting">genre painting</a>s, ranging from elegant <a href="merry%20companies">merry companies</a> to <a href="guardroom%20scene">guardroom scene</a>s and (most numerous) groups of peasants, in a variety of styles which can be related to those of leading artists in these genres, but with personal aspects in the colouring and style. They "are heavily and powerfully rendered in warm shades of brown, set off by strong local colouring in the principal figures. His successful peasant scenes are characterized by the use of strong chiaroscuro and a gentle, harmonious palette. The caricatural quality of Quast’s peasants recalls the work of his fellow-resident of The Hague, <a href="Adriaen%20van%20de%20Venne">Adriaen van de Venne</a>, but Quast’s looser style and many of his individual types are closer to the paintings of <a href="Adriaen%20Brouwer">Adriaen Brouwer</a>, as well as of <a href="Adriaen%20van%20Ostade">Adriaen van Ostade</a>, to whom Quast’s best work has sometimes been ascribed". He also produced finished drawings for sale, often on <a href="parchment">parchment</a>, and these included landscapes and cityscapes. Some of his works were engraved, though it is not clear if he did this himself.
Quast was probably born and certainly died in <a href="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a>, but from 1634 to 1641 he lived at <a href="The%20Hague">The Hague</a>, where he was admitted to the local <a href="Guild%20of%20Saint%20Luke">Guild of Saint Luke</a> in 1634. His pupil was <a href="Jan%20Jansz%20Buesem">Jan Jansz Buesem</a>. He died in poverty, like many artists of the period.
